elements.content: The synthesis and characterization of the novel systems [Zn2(H2N(CH2)2NH2)5][{Zn(H2N(CH2)2NH2)2}2V18O42(H2O)]·9H2O (1), [Cd2(H2N(CH2)2NH2)5][{Cd(H2N(CH2)2NH2)2}2V18O42(Br)]·9H2O (2), and [Zn2(H2N(CH2)2NH2)5][{Zn(H2N(CH2)2NH2)2}2V18O42(Cl)]·9H2O (3) have been described. These materials represent a new class of solids that have been prepared by combining conventional coordination compounds with spherical polyoxovanadate clusters. The isomorphous structures of these hybrid solids consist of two-dimensional arrays of container cluster molecules {V18O42(X)} (X = H2O, Br-, Cl-) interlinked by the transition metal complex moieties {M(H2N(CH2)2NH2)2} (M = Zn, Cd). These compounds contain an unprecedented complex cation, [M2(H2N(CH2)2NH2)5]4+. Crystal data for 1:  C9H46N9O26V9Zn2, monoclinic space group P21/m (No. 11), a = 12.3723(7) Å, b = 20.9837(11) Å, c = 15.8379(8) Å, β = 97.3320(10)°, Z = 4.

These materials represent a new class of solids that have been prepared by combining conventional coordination compounds with spherical polyoxovanadate clusters. These compounds contain an unprecedented complex cation, [M2(H2N(CH2)2NH2)5]4+. Crystal data for 1: C9H46N9O26V9Zn2, monoclinic space group P21/m (No. 11), a = 12.3723(7) Å, b = 20.9837(11) Å, c = 15.8379(8) Å, β = 97.3320(10)°, Z = 4.

elements.content: A novel series of solids composed of two-dimensional arrays of vanadium oxide container molecules, {V18O42(X)} (X = H2O, Cl-, Br-), interlinked by complex moieties {M(H2N(CH2)2NH2)2} (M = Zn, Cd) have been prepared and characterized.

elements.content: The preparation of extended structure solids with controllable and desirable properties and functions is of both fundamental and practical interest. Among the prominent emerging concepts, the “molecular building block” approach is quite attractive and appears to hold the key to the development of rational approaches for tailor-making materials with desirable features. The crucial requirement for the success of this approach is the availability of suitable molecular units that could be readily assembled. Transition metal oxide clusters and their derivatives provide an exciting opportunity to explore the potential of this approach. These clusters provide a wide variety of robust structural motifs of different sizes and topologies. A large number of these molecular aggregates of dimensions up to several nanometers, containing up to thousands of metal centers fused by oxide ligands, and with molecular weights at par with proteins are known. These are potential building blocks for preparing novel solids whose performance and properties could possibly be rationalized in terms of their molecular constituents. Solids composed of nanometer size (1−100 nm) building units10 are especially of current interest. Control of the compositions and structures of these materials can result in enhanced and novel properties at the macroscale.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The preparation of extended structure solids with controllable and desirable properties and functions is of both fundamental and practical interest. Among the prominent emerging concepts, the "molecular building block" approach is quite attractive and appears to hold the key to the development of rational approaches for tailor-making materials with desirable features. The crucial requirement for the success of this approach is the availability of suitable molecular units that could be readily assembled. Transition metal oxide clusters and their derivatives provide an exciting opportunity to explore the potential of this approach. These clusters provide a wide variety of robust structural motifs of different sizes and topologies. A large number of these molecular aggregates of dimensions up to several nanometers, containing up to thousands of metal centers fused by oxide ligands, and with molecular weights at par with proteins are known. These are potential building blocks for preparing novel solids whose performance and properties could possibly be rationalized in terms of their molecular constituents. Solids composed of nanometer size (1-100 nm) building units10 are especially of current interest. Control of  the compositions and structures of these materials can result in enhanced and novel properties at the macroscale.

elements.content: We are currently investigating the possible application of large vanadium oxide clusters as molecular building blocks for the construction of new materials. Recently, we reported novel three-dimensional framework solids composed of molecular vanadium oxide clusters. By combining conventional coordination compounds with polyoxovanadate clusters, we have now succeeded in preparing a new class of layered solids composed of two-dimensional arrays of the container cluster molecules {V18O42(X)} (X = H2O, Br-, Cl-) interlinked by the transition metal complex moieties {M(H2N(CH2)2NH2)2} (M = Zn, Cd). Here we describe the synthesis and characterization of the following new systems which also contain an unprecedented complex cation, [M2(H2N(CH2)2NH2)5]4+:

Materials. All chemicals used during the course of this investigation were of reagent grade. These were used as received from a commercial source (Aldrich).

Methods. IR spectra (KBr Pellet; 4000−400 cm-1) were recorded on a Paragon 1000 FT-IR spectrophotometer. Thermal analysis data were obtained by using a Universal V2.5H thermal analyzer. Typically, 20−30 mg of sample was placed in a quartz bucket and heated in an argon flow of 50 mL/min with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. The residues from TGA experiments were examined by IR spectroscopy. Titration of reduced vanadium (VIV) sites in the compound was performed on a Mettler Toledo DL12 titrator using dilute sulfuric acid solutions of 1−3 and standardized KMnO4 solutions.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials. All chemicals used during the course of this investigation were of reagent grade. These were used as received from a commercial source (Aldrich). 

 Methods. IR spectra (KBr Pellet; 4000-400 cm-1) were recorded on a Paragon 1000 FT-IR spectrophotometer. Thermal analysis data were obtained by using a Universal V2.5H thermal analyzer. Typically, 20-30 mg of sample was placed in a quartz bucket and heated in an argon flow of 50 mL/min with a heating rate of 5 °C/min. The residues from TGA experiments were examined by IR spectroscopy. Titration of reduced vanadium (VIV) sites in the compound was performed on a Mettler Toledo DL12 titrator using dilute sulfuric acid solutions of 1-3 and standardized KMnO4 solutions.

elements.content: Synthesis of [Zn 2 (H 2 N(CH 2 ) 2 NH 2 ) 5 ][{Zn(H 2 N(CH 2 ) 2 NH 2 ) 2 } 2 -V 18 O 42 (H 2 O)]·9H 2 O, 1. Ethylenediamine (7.5 mmol) was added to the stirring slurry of V2O5 (1.25 mmol) in water (15 mL) contained in a 50 mL round-bottom flask and maintained at 80−84 °C. After the resulting brown colored solution was treated with hydrazinium sulfate (1.25 mmol), the reaction mixture was heated for another 30 min with continuous stirring to yield a dark greenish-black solution (pH ∼ 7.8). At this point, ZnSO4·7H2O (1.87 mmol) was added to the dark solution and the solution was refluxed for 24 h to give rodlike black crystals of 1. The crystals along with an amorphous gray impurity were filtered from the colorless mother liquor, washed with cold deionized water, and dried in air at room temperature. Finally, the crystals were mechanically separated from the gray impurity to give 0.35 g (∼83% yield based on vanadium) of 1. Characteristic FT-IR absorption bands (KBr pellet:  1200−400 cm-1 region), cm-1:  ν(V−Oterm) = 1009(m), 968(s), 935(sh); ν as(V−(μ 3-O)) = 708(s), 623(s), 506(m).

elements.content: Synthesis of [Cd 2 (H 2 N(CH 2 ) 2 NH 2 ) 5 ][{Cd(H 2 N(CH 2 ) 2 NH 2 ) 2 } 2 -V 18 O 42 (Br)]·9H 2 O, 2. It was synthesized by adopting the above method employed for making 1 except that the dark solution, obtained from the reaction of ethylenediamine, V2O5, and hydrazinium sulfate, was treated with CdSO4·7H2O (1.87 mmol) and tetrabutylammonium bromide (0.62 mmol) and the reaction mixture refluxed for 24 h. Black prism-shaped crystals of 2 were filtered along with an amorphous gray impurity from the mother liquor, washed with cold water, and dried in air at room temperature. The crystals were separated from the gray impurity to give 0.37 g (∼81% yield based on vanadium) of 2. The compound can also be prepared by using an equivalent amount of NaBr or KBr in place of tetrabutyammonium bromide in the above preparation method of 2. Characteristic FT-IR absorption bands (KBr pellet:  1200−400 cm-1 region), cm-1:  ν(V−Oterm) = 1009(sh), 962(s); ν as(V−(μ 3-O)) = 703(s), 622(s), 483(m).

The crystals were separated from the gray impurity to give 0.37 g (~81% yield based on vanadium) of 2. The compound can also be prepared by using an equivalent amount of NaBr or KBr in place of tetrabutyammonium bromide in the above preparation method of 2. elements.content: Synthesis of [Zn 2 (H 2 N(CH 2 ) 2 NH 2 ) 5 ][{Zn(H 2 N(CH 2 ) 2 NH 2 ) 2 } 2 -V 18 O 42 (Cl)]·9H 2 O, 3. A mixture consisting of V2O5 (1.25 mmol), ethylenediamine (7.5 mmol), zinc powder (2.5 mmol), MnCl2·4H2O (1.87 mmol), and H2O (555.55 mmol) in the molar ratio 1:6:2:1.5:444 was placed in a 23 mL Parr Teflon-lined autoclave. After the mixture was stirred for 30 s, the autoclave was sealed and subsequently heated for 48 h inside an electric furnace maintained at 135 °C. The autoclave was cooled for 2 h, and black needle shaped crystals mixed with a yellow powdery impurity were filtered from the colorless mother liquor. The crystals were thoroughly washed with deionized water, dried at room temperature, and mechanically separated from the powdery impurity to give 0.15 g (38% based on vanadium) of 3. Compound 3 can also be prepared in an analogous manner from a mixture consisting of V2O5 (1.25 mmol), ethylenediamine (7.5 mmol), zinc powder (2.5 mmol), ZnCl2·4H2O (1.87 mmol), and H2O (555.55 mmol). Characteristic FT-IR absorption bands (KBr pellet:  1200−400 cm-1 region), cm-1:  ν(V−Oterm) = 1010(m), 969(s), 935(sh); ν as(V−(μ 3-O)) = 717(s), 637(s), 507(m).

elements.content: X-ray Structure Analyses. The structures of the compounds were determined from single-crystal X-ray diffraction data collected on a Bruker SMART-CCD diffractometer (graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation; λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods (SHELXTL version 5.03) and refined by full-matrix least squares on F 2.

elements.content: A crystal of 1 of approximate dimensions 0.39 × 0.37 × 0.07 mm was immersed in Paratone oil and mounted on a glass fiber in the nitrogen cold stream of the diffractometer and centered. Preliminary unit cell parameters and crystal orientation were determined by standard procedures. A full sphere of diffraction data was collected in 20 s frames separated by 0.3° increments in ω. The first 50 frames were remeasured at the end of data collection as a check on crystal decay. A total of 43312 reflections (1.62° ≤ θ ≤ 28.30°) were collected, of which 10080 unique reflections were used for structural elucidation. Coverage of the unique data set was 96.8% complete to 28.30° in θ. The data were processed with the program SAINT and corrected for absorption (and other effects) with SADABS.

elements.content: All calculations were carried out by use of SHELXTL version 5.03. The structure was solved in monoclinic space group P21/m (No. 11) by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares techniques. At convergence, R1 was 0.0641 and the goodness-of-fit was 1.085. Summaries of the crystal data and details of the intensity data collection and structure refinement are given in Table ; full details have been deposited.

Rodlike crystals of 1 are readily prepared in high yield by the synthetic procedure described in the Experimental Section. The compound can also be prepared by other slightly modified methods. Black prism-shaped crystals of 2 were prepared in an analogous manner by using an equivalent amount of cadmium sulfate (in place of zinc sulfate) and a suitable bromide ion source (sodium bromide, potassium bromide, or tetrabutylammonium bromide) in the reaction. As expected from the composition of 2, the presence of the bromide ions in the reaction medium is crucial for its formation. A chloro analogue of 2 is obtained from similar reactions that employed chloride ion sources but no bromide ion. Hydrothermal reactions were conveniently employed for the synthesis of black needle-shaped crystals of 3. The manganese chloride used in the initial synthesis of 3 served as a source of chloride ions, which are essential for its formation. This is confirmed by the alternative hydrothermal synthesis of 3 from a reaction mixture that contained an equivalent amount of zinc chloride in place of manganese chloride. Presence of the zinc powder in the reaction mixture helps in obtaining single crystals of 3.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Rodlike crystals of 1 are readily prepared in high yield by the synthetic procedure described in the Experimental Section. The compound can also be prepared by other slightly modified methods. Black prism-shaped crystals of 2 were prepared in an analogous manner by using an equivalent amount of cadmium sulfate (in place of zinc sulfate) and a suitable bromide ion source (sodium bromide, potassium bromide, or tetrabutylammonium bromide) in the reaction. As expected from the composition of 2, the presence of the bromide ions in the reaction medium is crucial for its formation. A chloro analogue of 2 is obtained from similar reactions that employed chloride ion sources but no bromide ion. Hydrothermal reactions were conveniently employed for the synthesis of black needle-shaped crystals of 3. The manganese chloride used in the initial synthesis of 3 served as a source of chloride ions, which are essential for its formation. This is confirmed by the alternative hydrothermal synthesis of 3 from a reaction mixture that contained an equivalent amount of zinc chloride in place of manganese chloride. Presence of the zinc powder in the reaction mixture helps in obtaining single crystals of 3.

elements.content: The compounds have been characterized by elemental analysis, manganometric titration of the reduced VIV sites, bond valence sum calculations, FT-IR spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, and single-crystal X-ray structure analysis. The three compounds 1−3 have similar FT-IR spectra showing only slight shifts in some band positions. Besides exhibiting the diagnostic ethylenediamine bands in the 3400−3200 and 1600−1100 cm-1 regions, the infrared spectra also show characteristic absorption bands attributable to H2O, ν(V−Oterm), and ν(V−(μ3-O)) groups.

elements.content: Selected bond lengths and bond angles for 1 are listed in Table . The single crystals of 1−3 have closely related structures. In each case, the structure consists of composite layers composed of two-dimensional arrays of container cluster molecules {V18O42(X)} (X = H2O, 1; X = Br-, 2; X = Cl-, 3) and {M(H2N(CH2)2NH2)2} (M = Zn, 1, 3; M = Cd, 2) complex moieties. Each vanadium oxide cluster in the layers is interlinked to the four adjacent {V18O42(X)} units by four {M(H2N(CH2)2NH2)2} moieties that act as μ 2 bridging groups. This generates new anionic layers that are separated by the cations and solvate water molecules occupying the interlayer region.

The two-dimensional puckered sheets containing the vanadium oxide clusters are perpendicular to the c-axis. Figure shows a portion of a single layer projected perpendicular to the c-axis. The anionic layers are composed of arrays of interlinked {V18O42(H2O)} units.

elements.content: Figure shows the structure of the {V18O42(H2O)} cluster. The zinc atoms of the μ 2-{Zn(H2N(CH2)2NH2)2} bridging groups that link these clusters are also included in this diagram. This view, edge-on to the crystallographic mirror plane of the {V18O42} shell, shows how the cluster atoms are symmetry related. Two of the zinc atoms (Zn1 and Zn1A) that lie in the mirror plane are related by one lattice translation along the a-axis. The other two (Zn2 and Zn2A) are related by the mirror plane.

elements.content: The {V18O42} shells in 1−3 have essentially identical structures with approximate D 4 d symmetry. This is the same configuration observed earlier in the fully reduced molecular species Cs12[VIV 18O42(H2O)]·9H2O and related compounds. The shell in 1−3 hosts a water molecule (1), a bromide ion (2), or a chloride ion (3), respectively. The identity of the guest species has been established by a number of analytical methods. The ability of the {V18O42} shell to accommodate a variety of molecules and ions, its flexible electronic properties, and its variable geometries (T d , D 4 d , and O h symmetries) are remarkable.

The ability of the {V18O42} shell to accommodate a variety of molecules and ions, its flexible electronic properties, and its variable geometries (T  d , D 4  d , and O  h  symmetries) are remarkable.

elements.content: The {V18O42} shell is composed of 18 edge-sharing {VO5} square pyramids with an average V−V distance of 2.945 Å. The encapsulated water molecule in the shell has no appreciable interaction with the shell framework. The average distance of this water molecule from the V atoms of the shell is 3.778 Å. The relatively large thermal parameter for the oxygen atom of the guest water molecule is indicative of a degree of positional disorder. The geometry around each vanadium atom in 14 of the {VO5} groups is defined by a terminal oxo group and four μ 3-oxygen atoms. The vanadium atoms in the remaining four {VO5} units are bonded to four μ3-oxo groups and an apical μ 2-oxygen which bridges to the ZnII center of a bridging {Zn(H2N(CH2)2NH2)2} group. The V−O distances (Table ) and the bond valence sum calculations indicate no protonation of the {V18O42} oxygen atoms in 1. Manganometric titration shows 14 reduced (VIV) sites. The structural parameters for 1 suggest the delocalization of charge over all vanadium centers. Room temperature magnetic susceptibility measurement on a sample of 1 indicates the presence of strong antiferromagnetic coupling similar to that observed in previous studies.

elements.content: The bridging Zn centers are bound to two chelating ethylenediamine ligands (Zn−N = 2.100(6)−2.142(5) Å) and two trans μ 2-oxo groups (Zn−O = 2.252(6)−2.319(4) Å). The {V−O−Zn} bond angles range from 127.9(2)° to 137.2(3)°. The bent {V−O−Zn} linkages result in a puckering of the layers with alternating {V18O42(H2O)} units lying above and below the average plane of the layers.

The bent {V-O-Zn} linkages result in a puckering of the layers with alternating {V18O42(H2O)} units lying above and below the average plane of the layers.

elements.content: The [Zn2(H2N(CH2)2NH2)5]4+ cations and water molecules occupy the interlayer region in 1. The structure of the novel complex species, shown in Figure , consists of two {Zn(H2N(CH2)2NH2)2} moieties linked across an inversion center by a bridging ethylenediamine ligand. The pattern of bond lengths and angles about the five-coordinate zinc centers is best described as a distorted trigonal bipyramidal configuration, with the atoms N6 and N7 occupying the axial positions. The average Zn−N distance is 2.134 Å, which is somewhat shorter than the typical value (ca. 2.19 Å) observed in {Zn(H2N(CH2)2NH2)3]2+ species.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses (25−600 °C temperature range) of 1−3 showed weight losses corresponding to the removal of water of solvation at relatively lower temperature (below ∼80 °C), guest species, and ethylenediamine ligands. The thermogram for 1 revealed the removal of lattice water at ∼64 °C and the encapsulated water at ∼109 °C. This is followed by the complex multistep decomposition of the organic ligands in the 220−580 °C temperature range. The observed total weight loss is in good agreement with the calculated value.

elements.content: These results emphasize the potential of transition metal oxide clusters as molecular building blocks for constructing new materials. An increasingly large number of clusters containing up to thousands of metal atoms and oxide ligands are now available which, in principle, are building units for metal oxide based materials. As has become clear from recent work, the sizes of these clusters can be varied in incremental steps. This can have influence on their properties especially when the cluster sizes are in the nanodimension regime. This in turn might influence the bulk properties of the materials made from them. This could open new opportunities for possible tuning of the properties of materials and for studying structure−property relationships. Moreover, the construction of these new materials may also facilitate the formation of unexpected species such as the novel {M2(H2N(CH2)2NH2)5]4+ cation observed during the course of this work.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis of [Zn 2 (H 2 N(CH 2 ) 2 NH 2 ) 5 ][{Zn(H 2 N(CH 2 ) 2 NH 2 ) 2 } 2 -V 18 O 42 (H 2 O)]·9H 2 O, 1. Ethylenediamine (7.5 mmol) was added to the stirring slurry of V2O5 (1.25 mmol) in water (15 mL) contained in a 50 mL round-bottom flask and maintained at 80−84 °C. After the resulting brown colored solution was treated with hydrazinium sulfate (1.25 mmol), the reaction mixture was heated for another 30 min with continuous stirring to yield a dark greenish-black solution (pH ∼ 7.8). At this point, ZnSO4·7H2O (1.87 mmol) was added to the dark solution and the solution was refluxed for 24 h to give rodlike black crystals of 1. The crystals along with an amorphous gray impurity were filtered from the colorless mother liquor, washed with cold deionized water, and dried in air at room temperature. Finally, the crystals were mechanically separated from the gray impurity to give 0.35 g (∼83% yield based on vanadium) of 1. Characteristic FT-IR absorption bands (KBr pellet:  1200−400 cm-1 region), cm-1:  ν(V−Oterm) = 1009(m), 968(s), 935(sh); ν as(V−(μ 3-O)) = 708(s), 623(s), 506(m).

Synthesis of [Cd 2 (H 2 N(CH 2 ) 2 NH 2 ) 5 ][{Cd(H 2 N(CH 2 ) 2 NH 2 ) 2 } 2 -V 18 O 42 (Br)]·9H 2 O, 2. It was synthesized by adopting the above method employed for making 1 except that the dark solution, obtained from the reaction of ethylenediamine, V2O5, and hydrazinium sulfate, was treated with CdSO4·7H2O (1.87 mmol) and tetrabutylammonium bromide (0.62 mmol) and the reaction mixture refluxed for 24 h. Black prism-shaped crystals of 2 were filtered along with an amorphous gray impurity from the mother liquor, washed with cold water, and dried in air at room temperature. The crystals were separated from the gray impurity to give 0.37 g (∼81% yield based on vanadium) of 2. The compound can also be prepared by using an equivalent amount of NaBr or KBr in place of tetrabutyammonium bromide in the above preparation method of 2. Characteristic FT-IR absorption bands (KBr pellet:  1200−400 cm-1 region), cm-1:  ν(V−Oterm) = 1009(sh), 962(s); ν as(V−(μ 3-O)) = 703(s), 622(s), 483(m).

Synthesis of [Zn 2 (H 2 N(CH 2 ) 2 NH 2 ) 5 ][{Zn(H 2 N(CH 2 ) 2 NH 2 ) 2 } 2 -V 18 O 42 (Cl)]·9H 2 O, 3. A mixture consisting of V2O5 (1.25 mmol), ethylenediamine (7.5 mmol), zinc powder (2.5 mmol), MnCl2·4H2O (1.87 mmol), and H2O (555.55 mmol) in the molar ratio 1:6:2:1.5:444 was placed in a 23 mL Parr Teflon-lined autoclave. After the mixture was stirred for 30 s, the autoclave was sealed and subsequently heated for 48 h inside an electric furnace maintained at 135 °C. The autoclave was cooled for 2 h, and black needle shaped crystals mixed with a yellow powdery impurity were filtered from the colorless mother liquor. The crystals were thoroughly washed with deionized water, dried at room temperature, and mechanically separated from the powdery impurity to give 0.15 g (38% based on vanadium) of 3. Compound 3 can also be prepared in an analogous manner from a mixture consisting of V2O5 (1.25 mmol), ethylenediamine (7.5 mmol), zinc powder (2.5 mmol), ZnCl2·4H2O (1.87 mmol), and H2O (555.55 mmol). Characteristic FT-IR absorption bands (KBr pellet:  1200−400 cm-1 region), cm-1:  ν(V−Oterm) = 1010(m), 969(s), 935(sh); ν as(V−(μ 3-O)) = 717(s), 637(s), 507(m).

cln_elements.content: The synthesis and characterization of the novel systems [Zn2(H2N(CH2)2NH2)5][{Zn(H2N(CH2)2NH2)2}2V18O42(H2O)]·9H2O (1), [Cd2(H2N(CH2)2NH2)5][{Cd(H2N(CH2)2NH2)2}2V18O42(Br)]·9H2O (2), and [Zn2(H2N(CH2)2NH2)5][{Zn(H2N(CH2)2NH2)2}2V18O42(Cl)]·9H2O (3) have been described. These materials represent a new class of solids that have been prepared by combining conventional coordination compounds with spherical polyoxovanadate clusters. The isomorphous structures of these hybrid solids consist of two-dimensional arrays of container cluster molecules {V18O42(X)} (X = H2O, Br-, Cl-) interlinked by the transition metal complex moieties {M(H2N(CH2)2NH2)2} (M = Zn, Cd). These compounds contain an unprecedented complex cation, [M2(H2N(CH2)2NH2)5]4+. Crystal data for 1:  C9H46N9O26V9Zn2, monoclinic space group P21/m (No. 11), a = 12.3723(7) Å, b = 20.9837(11) Å, c = 15.8379(8) Å, β = 97.3320(10)°, Z = 4.
